review.title: On-Line Portfolio Selection with Moving Average Reversion
review.abstract: On-line portfolio selection has attracted increasing interests in machine learning and AI communities recently. Empirical evidences show that stock's high and low prices are temporary and stock price relatives are likely to follow the mean reversion phenomenon. While the existing mean reversion strategies are shown to achieve good empirical performance on many real datasets, they often make the single-period mean reversion assumption, which is not always satisfied in some real datasets, leading to poor performance when the assumption does not hold. To overcome the limitation, this article proposes a multiple-period mean reversion, or so-called Moving Average Reversion (MAR), and a new on-line portfolio selection strategy named "On-Line Moving Average Reversion" (OLMAR), which exploits MAR by applying powerful online learning techniques. From our empirical results, we found that OLMAR can overcome the drawback of existing mean reversion algorithms and achieve significantly better results, especially on the datasets where the existing mean reversion algorithms failed. In addition to superior trading performance, OLMAR also runs extremely fast, further supporting its practical applicability to a wide range of applications.

sections.heading: 4.4. Analysis
sections.text: The update of OLMAR is simple, that is, bt + 1 = bt + λt + 1 (x-t + 1 − x-t + 11). Essentially, the update divides the assets into two groups by the forecast average. For the assets in the group with higher predictions than average, OLMAR increases its shares, for the others OLMAR reduces its shares. The transferred shares are related to the surprise of the predictions above average and the positive lagrange multiplier, λ. This is in line with the normal procedure of portfolio selection, i.e. the transfer of assets to the assets with better growth opportunities. The OLMAR update clearly costs linear time per period, and the normalization step can also be implemented in linear time (Duchi et al., 2008). To the best of knowledge, the linear time of OLMAR is no worse than any existing algorithm.

sections.heading: 5.3. Transaction Cost Scalability
sections.text: In order to evaluate the practicality, we evaluate the scalability of the proposed algorithms in terms of the proportional transaction costs (Borodin et al., 2004). Figure 4 illustrates the cumulative prosperity that OLMAR achieves with increasing transaction cost rate γ, and also the results obtained through four representative algorithms (two benchmarks and two state-of-the-art in different categories). On the one hand, the results clearly show that OLMAR can withstand reasonable transaction costs, as it often has high break-even rates in terms of the market. On the other hand, OLMAR can exceed benchmarks and state-of-the-art in various transaction costs. In a word, OLMAR performs excellently when trade is not smooth, which supports its practicality.

sections.heading: 5.4. Computational Time
sections.text: Finally, we evaluate the computing time as shown in Table 1 (c). Note that we only list the computing times of methods with comparable performance. In theory, as we have analyzed in Section 4.4, OLMAR enjoys a linear computing time complexity. Empirically, as shown in the table, the OLMAR algorithm takes the smallest times for all data sets. Note that with daily frequency, the average times of competitors are acceptable, but their times are not acceptable in the high frequency trading scenario. This time efficiency supports OLMAR's large-scale real-scale applications.

sections.heading: 5.5. Discussion and Thread of Validity
sections.text: Without a theoretical guarantee, the empirical assumptions in Section 2 are worth reviewing as performed by all existing heuristic algorithms (Borodin et al., 2004; Li et al., 2011a; b; 2012). As evaluated in Section 5.3, OLMAR can withstand reasonable transaction costs. All data sets consist of the largest index composite stocks with the best market liquidity. To limit the market impact when the portfolio is too large, one solution is to reduce the size of the portfolio, as is done by several quantitative funds. At this point, we reiterate that even in such a "perfect market," no algorithm has ever performed so well. There may also be certain problems in the retesting. One possible problem is "survival bias." As the composite stocks have never been disconnected from the markets after existing work and have survived for a long time, in particular the two NYSE data sets.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: This paper proposes a novel online portfolio selection strategy called "On-Line Moving Average Reversion" (OLMAR), which exploits "Moving Average Reversion" through online learning algorithms. It can solve the state-of-the-art problems caused by the one-time reversal of funds and achieve satisfactory results in real markets. It is also extremely fast and suitable for large-scale real-world applications. In the future, we will further explore the theoretical aspect of the reversal of funds.
